1138118_11_ITEM7_P74_S11	The increase was primarily driven by higher payroll-related costs, including bonuses, which resulted from our improved operating performance as well as the restoration of salaries to pre-recession levels in the third quarter of 2010 and substantially restored bonus target levels in the fourth quarter of 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P74_S12	Also contributing to the increase was higher carried interest incentive compensation expense accruals and increased marketing and travel costs in support of our growing revenue in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S0	Foreign currency translation had a $10.8 million negative impact on total operating expenses during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S1	Operating expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased to 31.4% for the year ended December 31, 2010 from 33.2% for the year ended December 31, 2009, reflective of our cost containment efforts during the recessionary period of 2008 and 2009 as well as the strong improvement in overall revenue.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S2	Our depreciation and amortization expense on a consolidated basis increased by $8.9 million, or 9.0%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S3	This increase was primarily attributable to higher depreciation expense within our Global Investment Management segment driven by the consolidation of several assets due to the adoption of ASU 2009-17 in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S4	Our gain on disposition of real estate on a consolidated basis was $7.3 million and $7.0 million for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S5	These gains resulted from activity within our Development Services segment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S6	Our equity income from unconsolidated subsidiaries on a consolidated basis was $26.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to an equity loss from unconsolidated subsidiaries of $34.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S7	The increase in equity income in the current year was primarily driven by higher equity earnings associated with gains on property sales within our Development Services segment and higher equity earnings in our Global Investment Management segment largely resulting from a fund liquidation.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S8	Also contributing to the variance were lower impairment charges associated with equity investments in our Development Services and Global Investment Management segments in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S9	Our consolidated interest income was $8.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, an increase of $2.3 million, or 37.3%, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S10	This increase was mainly driven by higher interest income reported in our Asia Pacific segment, which resulted from the final measurement of a deferred purchase obligation related to the purchase of remaining non-controlling interests in our subsidiary in India.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P75_S11	Our consolidated interest expense increased by $2.0 million, or 1.1%, during the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S0	consolidation of several assets due to the adoption of ASU 2009-17 in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S1	These increases were largely offset by lower interest expense associated with our credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S2	We wrote off $18.1 million and $29.3 million of financing costs during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S3	In connection with the new credit agreement we entered into on November 10, 2010, we wrote off financing costs of $16.7 million during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S4	In addition, in October 2010, we wrote off $1.4 million of unamortized deferred financing costs in connection with debt repayments made.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S5	In connection with the March 24, 2009 amendment and restatement of our previous credit agreement, we wrote off financing costs of $29.3 million during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S6	Our provision for income taxes on a consolidated basis was $130.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to $27.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S7	Our effective tax rate from continuing operations, after adjusting pre-tax income (loss) to remove the portion attributable to non-controlling interests, decreased to 40.5% for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to 44.7% for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S8	The changes in our provision for income taxes and our effective tax rate were primarily the result of a significant increase in income reported in the current year as well as a change in our mix of domestic and foreign earnings (losses).
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S9	Our consolidated income from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, was $14.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S10	This income was reported in our Development Services segment and mostly related to gains from asset dispositions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S11	Our net loss attributable to non-controlling interests on a consolidated basis was $44.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to $61.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S12	This activity primarily reflects our non-controlling interests share of losses within our Global Investment Management and Development Services segments.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S13	Year Ended December 31, 2009 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2008 We reported consolidated net income of $33.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 on revenue of $4.2 billion as compared to a consolidated net loss of $1.0 billion on revenue of $5.1 billion for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S14	Our revenue on a consolidated basis for the year ended December 31, 2009 decreased by $963.0 million, or 18.8%, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S15	This decrease was primarily driven by weak worldwide sales and leasing activity as well as lower appraisal revenue, all resulting from the continuation of challenging global economic conditions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S16	While our outsourcing business continued to add new clients and expand existing relationships, its revenue also declined slightly in 2009 as a result of reduced client spending, a rise in vacancy rates of properties we manage as well as the effect of client consolidations and distress during 2008 and 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S17	Foreign currency translation had a $129.2 million negative impact on total revenue during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P76_S18	Our cost of services on a consolidated basis decreased by $478.8 million, or 16.4%, during the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S0	As previously mentioned, our sales and leasing professionals generally are paid on a commission and bonus basis, which substantially correlates with our revenue performance.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S1	Accordingly, the decrease in revenue led to a corresponding decrease in commissions and bonuses.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S2	Foreign currency translation had an $83.9 million positive impact on cost of services during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S3	Cost of services as a percentage of revenue increased from 57.1% for the year ended December 31, 2008 to 58.8% for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S4	This increase was primarily driven by the large decrease in overall revenue and a shift in the mix of revenues with outsourcing, including reimbursables, comprising a materially greater portion of the total than in 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P77_S5	Our operating, administrative and other expenses on a consolidated basis decreased by $363.5 million, or 20.8%, during the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S0	lower operating costs, particularly payroll-related, travel and marketing costs.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S1	The decrease was also driven by reduced bonus expense resulting from lower business performance.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S2	Foreign currency translation had a $40.9 million positive impact on total operating expenses during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S3	As a result of our aggressive cost cutting measures, operating expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased to 33.2% for the year ended December 31, 2009 from 34.1% for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S4	Our depreciation and amortization expense on a consolidated basis decreased by $3.3 million, or 3.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S5	This decline was mainly driven by lower depreciation expense resulting from decreased capital expenditures.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S6	Our goodwill and other non-amortizable intangible asset impairment on a consolidated basis was $1.2 billion for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S7	These impairment charges were primarily driven by adverse economic conditions causing a decline in the estimated future discounted cash flows for several of our reporting units.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S8	Our gain on disposition of real estate on a consolidated basis was $7.0 million and $18.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S9	These gains resulted from activity within our Development Services segment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S10	Our equity loss from unconsolidated subsidiaries on a consolidated basis decreased by $46.0 million, or 57.5%, for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S11	This decrease was primarily driven by lower non-cash write-downs resulting from declines in value of investments in our Development Services and Global Investment Management segments in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S12	Also contributing to this variance was a $14.7 million non-cash write-down of our investment in Realty Finance Corporation, a mortgage REIT, within our Americas segment attributable to a decline in its market valuation in 2008, which did not recur in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S13	Our consolidated interest income was $6.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, a decrease of $11.6 million, or 65.5%, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S14	This decrease was mainly driven by lower interest income earned in our Development Services segment due to a decrease in notes receivable in 2009 and in our Americas and EMEA segments as a result of lower interest rates in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S15	Our consolidated interest expense increased by $22.0 million during the year ended December 31, 2009, or 13.2%, as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S16	The increase was primarily due to higher interest expense associated with the $450.0 million of 11.625% senior subordinated notes issued in June 2009, partially offset by lower interest expense associated with our previous credit agreement, mainly due to lower average outstanding debt balances in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S17	We wrote off $29.3 million of financing costs during the year ended December 31, 2009 in connection with the amendment of our previous credit agreement on March 24, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S18	Our provision for income taxes on a consolidated basis was $27.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to $50.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S19	Our effective tax rate from continuing operations, after adjusting pre-tax loss to remove the portion attributable to non-controlling interests, increased to 44.7% for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to negative 5.2% for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S20	The changes in our provision for income taxes and our effective tax rate were primarily the result of a sizeable loss reported in 2008 versus income in 2009, a change in our mix of domestic and foreign earnings (losses) as well as a large portion of the goodwill impairment charges incurred in 2008 being non-deductible for U.S. income tax purposes.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S21	Our consolidated income from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, was $26.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S22	This income was reported in our Development Services segment and mostly related to gains from asset dispositions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S23	Our net loss attributable to non-controlling interests on a consolidated basis was $61.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to $37.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P78_S24	This activity primarily reflects our non-controlling interests share of losses within our Development Services segment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P79_S0	Segment Operations We report our operations through the following segments: (1) Americas, (2) EMEA, (3) Asia Pacific, (4) Global Investment Management and (5) Development Services.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P80_S0	The Americas consists of operations located in the United States, Canada and selected parts of Latin America.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P80_S1	EMEA mainly consists of operations in Europe, while Asia Pacific includes operations in Asia, Australia and New Zealand.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P80_S2	The Global Investment Management business consists of investment management operations in the United States, Europe and Asia.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P80_S3	The Development Services business consists of real estate development and investment activities primarily in the United States.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S1	This improvement was primarily driven by higher sales and leasing activity as well as increased commercial mortgage brokerage and outsourcing activity.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S3	Cost of services increased by $365.8 million, or 22.2%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009, primarily due to increased commission expense resulting from higher sales and lease transaction revenue.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S4	In addition, commission reinstatements contributed to the increase.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S5	Higher salaries and related costs associated with our property and facilities management contracts also contributed to an increase in cost of services in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S6	Foreign currency translation had an $18.3 million negative impact on cost of services during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S7	Cost of services as a percentage of revenue decreased to 62.6% for the year ended December 31, 2010 from 63.6% for the year ended December 31, 2009 primarily due to the increase in overall revenue and a shift in the mix of revenue, with transaction revenue comprising a greater portion of the total than in the prior year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S8	Operating, administrative and other expenses increased by $114.3 million, or 16.2%.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S9	The increase was primarily driven by higher payroll-related costs, including bonuses, which resulted from our improved operating performance as well as the restoration of salaries to pre-recession levels in the third quarter of 2010 and substantially restored bonus target levels in the fourth quarter of 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P82_S10	Also contributing to the increase were higher marketing and travel costs in support of our growing revenue.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P84_S7	This increase was primarily driven by higher bonus accruals, which resulted from our improved operating performance, and higher marketing and travel costs in support of our growing revenue.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S4	Also contributing to the increase was higher bonus expense, which resulted from our improved operating performance.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S6	Global Investment Management Revenue increased by $74.2 million, or 52.4%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S7	This was largely due to an increase in rental revenue driven by the consolidation of several assets due to the adoption of ASU 2009-17 in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S8	Excluding the impact of this adoption, revenue increased by $39.7 million, primarily due to $19.9 million of carried interest revenue from a fund liquidation in the current year and higher acquisition fees resulting from increased capital deployment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S9	Foreign currency translation had a $1.5 million negative impact on total revenue during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S10	Operating, administrative and other expenses increased by $57.8 million, or 48.2%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S11	This increase was primarily driven by higher carried interest incentive compensation expense accruals for dedicated Global Investment Management executives and team leaders with participation interests in certain real estate investments under management, which totaled $19.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 versus a net reversal of $9.6 million in the prior year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S12	Also contributing to the increase in total operating expenses was a $20.9 million impact from the adoption of ASU 2009-17 and higher bonus expense resulting from our improved operating performance.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S15	Development Services Revenue decreased by $12.1 million, or 13.8%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009 primarily due to lower construction revenue and development fees, both driven by the continuation of weak market conditions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S16	Operating, administrative and other expenses decreased by $27.6 million, or 20.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S17	This decrease was primarily driven by lower impairment charges related to real estate assets and notes receivable in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S18	Also contributing to the decrease in the current year was a reduction in payroll-related costs largely resulting from cost containment efforts, lower property operating expenses as a result of property dispositions, and lower job construction costs, which correlated with the above-mentioned construction revenue decrease.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P86_S19	These decreases were partially offset by higher bonus accruals resulting from improved business performance primarily from gains on property sales in the current year.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S6	Operating, administrative and other expenses decreased by $161.9 million, or 18.6%, mainly driven by cost containment measures put in place in 2008 and 2009, which led to a reduction in operating costs, particularly lower payroll-related, travel and marketing costs.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S12	This decrease was driven by foreign currency translation, which had a $53.8 million positive impact on cost of services during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S13	Lower bonuses and commission expense resulting from lower revenue also contributed to the variance.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S14	Cost of services as a percentage of revenue increased from 56.7% for the year ended December 31, 2008 to 59.1% for the year ended December 31, 2009, primarily driven by the sharp decline in revenue.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S15	Operating, administrative and other expenses decreased by $100.7 million, or 27.5%, mainly due to aggressive actions taken to cut costs, which led to a reduction in operating costs, particularly lower payroll-related, travel and marketing costs.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S16	A reduction in bonuses resulting from the lower business performance also contributed to the variance.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S17	Foreign currency translation had a $26.7 million positive impact on total operating expenses during the year ended December 31, 2009.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P88_S19	This revenue decrease was primarily driven by lower sales and leasing activity throughout the region.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S1	This decrease was primarily due to lower operating costs, including payroll-related, travel and marketing costs, which were driven by cost containment measures put in place during 2008 and 2009.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S3	Global Investment Management Revenue decreased by $19.8 million, or 12.3%, for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008 due to lower asset management, acquisition, disposition and incentive fees in 2009 resulting from the continuation of constraints in the capital markets.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S6	This slight decline was primarily due to a reduction in bonuses, which resulted from the lower business performance, and lower operating costs, particularly travel, driven by cost containment measures put in place in 2008 and 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S7	These decreases were mostly offset by a lower net reversal of carried interest incentive compensation expense in 2009 for dedicated Global Investment Management executives and team leaders with participation interests in certain real estate investments under management.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S8	Excluding the impact of reversing net carried interest incentive compensation expense accruals, which totaled $9.6 million and $33.1 million for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, respectively, operating expenses decreased by 15.7% compared with 2008.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S11	Development Services Revenue decreased by $31.1 million, or 26.1%, for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008 primarily due to lower construction revenue and development fees driven by weak market conditions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S12	Operating, administrative and other expenses decreased by $73.7 million, or 35.2%, for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S13	The decrease was primarily driven by lower impairment charges related to real estate assets, which totaled $38.6 million and $59.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S14	Also contributing to the decrease in 2009 were lower construction costs and a decrease in payroll-related costs, including bonuses, as a result of lower business performance in 2009 as well as cost containment efforts in 2008 through 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S15	Development projects in process as of December 31, 2009 totaled $4.7 billion, down 16% from year-end 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P89_S16	The inventory of pipeline deals as of December 31, 2009 stood at $0.9 billion, down 64% from year-end 2008 as a result of the weak market conditions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P90_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources We believe that we can satisfy our working capital requirements and funding of investments with internally generated cash flow and, as necessary, borrowings under our revolving credit facility.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P90_S1	Our expected capital requirements for 2011 include up to $100 million of anticipated net capital expenditures.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P90_S2	As of December 31, 2010, we had committed to fund $22.0 million of additional capital to unconsolidated subsidiaries within our Development Services business, which we may be required to fund at any time.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P91_S0	Management business, all of which is expected to be funded in 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P92_S0	In recent years, the global credit markets have experienced unprecedented tightening, which could affect both the availability and cost of our funding sources in the future.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S0	On February 15, 2011, we announced that we had entered into definitive agreements to acquire the majority of the real estate investment management business of Netherlands-based ING for approximately $940 million in cash.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S1	The acquisitions include substantially all of the ING REIM operations in Europe and Asia, as well as CRES, its U.S.-based global real estate listed securities business.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S2	We also expect to acquire approximately $55 million of CRES co-investments from ING and potentially additional interests in other funds managed by ING REIM Europe and ING REIM Asia.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S3	In addition, we expect to incur transaction costs relating to the acquisitions of approximately $150 million (pre-tax), including financing, retention and integration costs.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S4	The acquisitions are expected to close in the second half of 2011 and are subject to approval by certain stakeholders, including regulatory agencies in the United States, Europe and Asia.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S5	We plan to finance the acquisitions with cash on hand and borrowings under our credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S6	During 2003 and 2006, we required substantial amounts of equity and debt financing to fund our acquisitions of Insignia and Trammell Crow Company.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S7	In the past two years, we also conducted two debt offerings.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S8	The first, in 2009, was part of a capital restructuring in response to the global economic recession, and the second, in 2010, was to take advantage of low interest rates and term availability.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S9	Absent extraordinary transactions such as these and the equity offerings we completed during the unprecedented recent global capital markets disruption in 2008 and 2009, we historically have not sought external sources of financing and have relied on our internally generated cash flow and our revolving credit facility to fund our working capital, capital expenditure and investment requirements.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P93_S10	In the absence of such extraordinary events, our management anticipates that our cash flow from operations and our revolving credit facility would be sufficient to meet our anticipated cash requirements for the foreseeable future, but at a minimum for the next 12 months.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P94_S0	As evidenced above, from time to time, we consider potential strategic acquisitions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P94_S1	Our management believes that any future significant acquisitions that we make most likely would require us to obtain additional debt or equity financing.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P94_S2	In the past, we have been able to obtain such financing for material transactions on terms that our management believed to be reasonable.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P94_S3	However, it is possible that we may not be able to find acquisition financing on favorable terms in the future if we decide to make any further material acquisitions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P95_S0	Our long-term liquidity needs, other than those related to ordinary course obligations and commitments such as operating leases, generally are comprised of three elements.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P96_S0	The first is the repayment of the outstanding and anticipated principal amounts of our long-term indebtedness.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P96_S1	Our management is unable to project with certainty whether our long-term cash flow from operations will be sufficient to repay our long-term debt when it comes due.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P96_S2	If this cash flow is insufficient, then our management expects that we would need to refinance such indebtedness or otherwise amend its terms to extend the maturity dates.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P96_S3	Our management cannot make any assurances that such refinancings or amendments would be available on attractive terms, if at all.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S0	The second long-term liquidity need is the repayment of obligations under our pension plans in the United Kingdom.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S1	Our subsidiaries based in the United Kingdom maintain two contributory defined benefit pension plans to provide retirement benefits to existing and former employees participating in the plans.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S2	With respect to these plans, our historical policy has been to contribute annually, an amount to fund pension cost as actuarially determined and as required by applicable laws and regulations.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S3	Our contributions to these plans are invested and, if these investments do not perform in the future as well as we expect, we will be required to provide additional funding to cover any shortfall.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S4	During 2007, we reached agreements with the active members of these plans to freeze future pension plan benefits.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S5	In return, the active members became eligible to enroll in the CBRE Group Personal Pension Plan, a defined contribution plan in the United Kingdom.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S6	The underfunded status of our defined benefit pension plans included in pension liability in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets was $40.0 million and $64.9 million at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P97_S7	We expect to contribute a total of $3.6 million to fund our pension plans for the year ending December 31, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P98_S0	The third long-term liquidity need is the repayment of obligations related to acquisitions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P98_S1	For example, in connection with our acquisitions of CB Richard Ellis KK (Japan) in 2006 and CB Richard Ellis South Asia Pte Ltd (India) in 2007, we incurred obligations with respect to the future purchase of non-controlling interests in such entities.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P98_S2	As of December 31, 2009, we had $58.5 million of these deferred purchase obligations outstanding, which were included in accounts payable and accrued expenses in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P98_S3	During the year ended December 31, 2010, we purchased the remaining non-controlling interests in Japan and India.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P98_S4	As of December 31, 2010, there were no deferred purchase obligations outstanding.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S0	On June 10, 2009, we completed the sale of 13,440,860 shares of our Class A common stock through a direct placement to Paulson Co. Inc., which raised approximately $97.6 million of net proceeds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S1	On June 11, 2009, we completed the sale of 5,682,684 shares of our Class A common stock through an at-the-market offering program, which raised approximately $48.8 million of net proceeds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S2	The net proceeds from these offerings were used for general corporate purposes, including the repayment of some of our outstanding indebtedness under our previous credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S3	In November 2009, we completed the sale of 28,289,960 shares of our Class A common stock pursuant to an at-the-market offering program, which raised approximately $293.8 million of net proceeds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S4	We used the proceeds from the offering for general corporate purposes, including the repayment of debt.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S5	Net cash provided by operating activities totaled $616.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, an increase of $402.9 million as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S6	The increase was primarily due to improved operating performance, higher net payments to vendors and to employees under our deferred compensation plan in the prior year and an increase in commission, bonus and income tax accruals in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S7	These items were partially offset by a greater increase in receivables and higher bonuses paid in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S8	Net cash provided by operating activities totaled $213.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2009 as compared to net cash used in operating activities of $130.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S9	The sharp increase in cash provided by operating activities during the year ended December 31, 2009 versus 2008 was primarily due to significantly lower bonus payments, income taxes and payments to vendors made in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P99_S10	These decreases were partially offset by lower results in 2009 (excluding the impact of non-cash impairment charges) as well as the impact of a significant decrease in receivables in 2008 versus a slight increase in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S0	Investing Activities Net cash used in investing activities totaled $62.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, a decrease of $56.9 million as compared to the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S1	The decrease was primarily driven by higher net proceeds received in the current year from the disposition of real estate held for investment and from the sale of servicing rights and other assets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S2	A decrease in restricted cash and lower contributions to investments in unconsolidated subsidiaries along with higher distributions received from investments in unconsolidated subsidiaries in the current year also contributed to the decrease.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S3	These decreases were partially offset by the use of more cash in the current year for capital expenditures and earn out payments associated with in-fill acquisitions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S4	Net cash used in investing activities totaled $119.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, a decrease of $299.6 million as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P100_S5	The decrease was primarily driven by the use of more cash in 2008 for in-fill acquisitions and purchases of real estate held for investment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S0	Financing Activities Net cash used in financing activities totaled $784.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to net cash provided by financing activities of $476.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S1	The sharp decrease in cash provided by financing activities was primarily due to higher net repayments of our senior secured term loans in the current year as well as proceeds received in the prior year in connection with equity offerings and the issuance of our 11.625% senior subordinated notes.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S2	Also contributing to the decrease were higher net repayments of notes payable on real estate within our Development Services segment in the current year.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S3	These decreases were partially offset by proceeds received in the current year from the issuance of our 6.625% senior notes.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S4	Net cash provided by financing activities totaled $476.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, an increase of $102.8 million as compared to the year ended December 31, 2008.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S5	The increase was largely due to higher net proceeds received in connection with equity offerings in 2009 and the issuance of our 11.625% senior subordinated notes in June 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S6	These increases were partially offset by activity under our credit agreement, including $300.0 million of proceeds received from an additional term loan in connection with the exercise of the accordion provision of our credit agreement in 2008, partially offset by lower net borrowings under our revolving credit facility in 2008 as well as higher repayments of the senior secured term loans in 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P101_S7	Also offsetting the overall increase was lower net proceeds from notes payable on real estate within our Development Services segment in 2009.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P111_S0	Our level of indebtedness increases the possibility that we may be unable to generate cash sufficient to pay when due the principal of, interest on or other amounts due in respect of our indebtedness and other obligations.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P111_S1	In addition, we may incur additional debt from time to time to finance strategic acquisitions, investments, joint ventures or for other purposes, subject to the restrictions contained in the documents governing our indebtedness.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P111_S2	If we incur additional debt, the risks associated with our leverage, including our ability to service our debt, would increase.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S0	Since 2001, we have maintained a credit agreement with Credit Suisse Group AG, or CS, and other lenders to fund strategic acquisitions and to provide for our working capital needs.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S1	On March 24, 2009, we entered into a second amendment and restatement to our credit agreement with a syndicate of banks led by CS, as administrative and collateral agent, amending and restating our amended and restated credit agreement dated December 20, 2006.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S2	In connection with this amendment and restatement, we wrote off financing costs of $29.3 million during the year ended December 31, 2009, which included the write-off of $18.1 million of unamortized deferred financing costs and $11.2 million of credit agreement amendment fees paid in March 2009.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S3	On August 24, 2009, we entered into a loan modification agreement to our credit agreement, which included the conversion of $41.9 million of amounts outstanding under our revolving credit facility to term loans.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S4	On both February 5, 2010 and March 29, 2010, we entered into additional loan modification agreements to our credit agreement to further extend debt maturities and amortization schedules.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S5	On November 10, 2010, we entered into a new credit agreement (Credit Agreement), with a syndicate of banks led by CS, as administrative and collateral agent, which completely replaced our previous credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S6	In connection with the establishment of the new Credit Agreement, we wrote off financing costs of $16.7 million during the year ended December 31, 2010, including $12.1 million of credit agreement amendment fees paid in November 2010 and $4.6 million of unamortized deferred financing costs associated with our prior credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P112_S7	In addition, in October 2010, we wrote off $1.4 million of unamortized deferred financing costs in connection with debt repayments made.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P114_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2010, we repaid $1.7 billion of our senior secured term loans under our previous credit agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P114_S1	In addition, we also made required principal payments of $9.5 million in December 2010 relative to senior secured term loans under our current Credit Agreement.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P114_S3	Additionally, outstanding borrowings under these sub-facilities may be up to 5.0% higher as allowed under the currency fluctuation provision in the Credit Agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P115_S0	Borrowings under the revolving credit facility as of December 31, 2010 bear interest at varying rates, based at our option, on either the applicable fixed rate plus 1.65% to 3.15% or the daily rate plus 0.65% to 2.15% as determined by reference to our ratio of total debt less available cash to EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Agreement).
1138118_11_ITEM7_P115_S1	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, we had $17.5 million and $21.1 million, respectively, of revolving credit facility principal outstanding with related weighted average interest rates of 3.5% and 5.3%, respectively, which are included in short-term borrowings in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P115_S3	These letters of credit were primarily issued in the normal course of business as well as in connection with certain insurance programs and reduce the amount we may borrow under the revolving credit facility.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P116_S0	Borrowings under the term loan facilities as of December 31, 2010 bear interest, based at our option, on the following: for the tranche A term loan facility, on either the applicable fixed rate plus 2.00% to 3.75% or the daily rate plus 1.00% to 2.75%, as determined by reference to our ratio of total debt less available cash to EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Agreement), and for the tranche B term loan facility, on either the applicable fixed rate plus 3.25% or the daily rate plus 2.25%.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P116_S1	As of December 31, 2010, we had $341.3 million of tranche A term loan facility principal outstanding and $299.2 million of tranche B term loan facility principal outstanding, which are included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P116_S2	As of December 31, 2009, we had $326.3 million of tranche A term loan facility principal outstanding, $48.6 million of tranche A-1 term loan facility principal outstanding, $203.2 million of tranche A-2 term loan facility principal outstanding, $167.5 million of tranche A-3 term loan facility principal outstanding, $642.8 million of tranche B term loan facility principal outstanding and $295.2 million of tranche B-1 term loan facility principal outstanding, which are also included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P117_S0	The Credit Agreement is jointly and severally guaranteed by us and substantially all of our domestic subsidiaries.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P117_S1	Borrowings under our Credit Agreement are secured by a pledge of substantially all of the capital stock of our U.S. subsidiaries and 65% of the capital stock of certain non-U.S. subsidiaries.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P117_S2	Also, the Credit Agreement requires us to pay a fee based on the total amount of the revolving credit facility commitment.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P118_S0	On February 17, 2011, we announced that we are embarking on the process of seeking commitments to fund up to an aggregate of $500.0 million of delayed draw, seven year senior secured term loans under a new Tranche C facility and up to an aggregate of $300.0 million of delayed draw, eight (or more) year senior secured term loans under a new Tranche D facility (together, the New Term Loans), the proceeds of which would be used to finance our recently announced REIM Acquisitions.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P118_S1	Additionally, we are embarking on the process of seeking an amendment to our Credit Agreement that, among other things, would (1) permit additional wholly-owned subsidiaries of the Company to be borrowers of the New Term Loans, (2) add an exception to the investment covenant relating to the REIM Acquisitions, (3) maintain the availability of the $800.0 million accordion provision under the Credit Agreement and (4) provide certain other ancillary amendments related thereto.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P118_S2	The terms of the New Term Loans and the proposed amendment are preliminary and subject to review and approval by us as well as the requisite lenders and, therefore, subject to further revision.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P119_S0	On October 8, 2010, CBRE issued $350.0 million in aggregate principal amount of 6.625% senior notes due October 15, 2020.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P120_S0	future subordinated indebtedness, but effectively subordinated to all of its current and future secured indebtedness.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S0	The 6.625% senior notes are jointly and severally guaranteed on a senior basis by us and each subsidiary of CBRE that guarantees our Credit Agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S1	Interest accrues at a rate of 6.625% per year and is payable semi-annually in arrears on April 15 and October 15, commencing on April 15, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S2	The 6.625% senior notes are redeemable at our option, in whole or in part, on or after October 15, 2014 at a redemption price of 104.969% of the principal amount on that date and at declining prices thereafter.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S3	At any time prior to October 15, 2014, the 6.625% senior notes may be redeemed by us, in whole or in part, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and an applicable premium (as defined in the indenture governing these notes), which is based on the present value of the October 15, 2014 redemption price plus all remaining interest payments through October 15, 2014.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S4	In addition, prior to October 15, 2013, up to 35.0% of the original issued amount of the 6.625% senior notes may be redeemed at a redemption price of 106.625% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, solely with the net cash proceeds from public equity offerings.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S5	If a change of control triggering event (as defined in the indenture governing our 6.625% senior notes) occurs, we are obligated to make an offer to purchase the remaining 6.625% senior notes at a redemption price of 101.0% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S6	The amount of the 6.625% senior notes included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets was $350.0 million at December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S7	On June 18, 2009, CBRE issued $450.0 million in aggregate principal amount of 11.625% senior subordinated notes due June 15, 2017 for approximately $435.9 million, net of discount.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S8	The 11.625% senior subordinated notes are unsecured senior subordinated obligations of CBRE and are jointly and severally guaranteed on a senior subordinated basis by us and our domestic subsidiaries that guarantee our Credit Agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S9	Interest accrues at a rate of 11.625% per year and is payable semi-annually in arrears on June 15 and December 15.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S10	The 11.625% senior subordinated notes are redeemable at our option, in whole or in part, on or after June 15, 2013 at 105.813% of par on that date and at declining prices thereafter.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S11	At any time prior to June 15, 2013, the 11.625% senior subordinated notes may be redeemed by us, in whole or in part, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and an applicable premium (as defined in the indenture governing these notes), which is based on the present value of the June 15, 2013 redemption price plus all remaining interest payments through June 15, 2013.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S12	In addition, prior to June 15, 2012, up to 35.0% of the original issued amount of the 11.625% senior subordinated notes may be redeemed at 111.625% of par, plus accrued and unpaid interest, solely with the net cash proceeds from public equity offerings.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S13	In the event of a change of control (as defined in the indenture governing our 11.625% senior subordinated notes), we are obligated to make an offer to purchase the remaining 11.625% senior subordinated notes at a redemption price of 101.0% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P121_S14	The amount of the 11.625% senior subordinated notes included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, net of unamortized discount, was $437.7 million and $436.5 million at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S0	Our Credit Agreement and the indentures governing our 6.625% senior notes and 11.625% senior subordinated notes contain numerous restrictive covenants that, among other things, limit our ability to incur additional indebtedness, pay dividends or make distributions to stockholders, repurchase capital stock or debt, make investments, sell assets or subsidiary stock, create or permit liens on assets, engage in transactions with affiliates, enter into sale/leaseback transactions, issue subsidiary equity and enter into consolidations or mergers.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S1	Our Credit Agreement also currently requires us to maintain a minimum coverage ratio of EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Agreement) to total interest expense of 2.25x and a maximum leverage ratio of total debt less available cash to EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Agreement) of 3.75x.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S2	Our coverage ratio of EBITDA to total interest expense was 8.16x for the year ended December 31, 2010 and our leverage ratio of total debt less available cash to EBITDA was 0.94x as of December 31, 2010.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S3	We may from time to time, in our sole discretion, look for opportunities to reduce our outstanding debt under our Credit Agreement and under our 6.625% senior notes and 11.625% senior subordinated notes.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S4	From time to time, Moody s Investor Service, Inc., or Moody s, and Standard Poor s Ratings Services, or Standard Poor s, rate our senior debt.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P122_S5	On October 5, 2010, Standard Poor s revised our outlook to stable from negative and affirmed our BB long-term counterparty credit rating.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S0	recovery rating of 6 was assigned to the 6.625% senior notes.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S1	Moody s assigned a (P)Ba1 rating to the $1.35 billion credit facility and a Ba1 rating to the 6.625% senior notes, and placed the 11.625% senior subordinated notes on review for upgrade.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S2	The rating outlook was revised to stable from negative.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S3	The (P) for the credit facility rating was removed on November 10, 2010 upon the closing of the new Credit Agreement, and the rating of the 11.625% senior subordinated notes was upgraded to Ba2.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S4	On February 16, 2011, Moody s affirmed its ratings on our existing senior debt.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S5	On February 17, 2011, Standard Poor s also affirmed its ratings on our existing senior debt as well as assigned a BB issue-level rating and a recovery rating of 4 to our planned $800 million in incremental credit facility borrowings.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S6	Neither the Moody s nor the Standard Poor s ratings impact our ability to borrow under our Credit Agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S7	However, these ratings may impact our ability to borrow under new agreements in the future and the interest rates of any such future borrowings.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P123_S8	We had short-term borrowings of $471.4 million and $339.8 million with related average interest rates of 2.8% and 2.4% as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P124_S0	On March 2, 2007, we entered into a $50.0 million credit note with Wells Fargo Bank for the purpose of purchasing eligible investments, which include cash equivalents, agency securities, A1/P1 commercial paper and eligible money market funds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P124_S1	The proceeds of this note are not made generally available to us, but instead deposited in an investment account maintained by Wells Fargo Bank and used and applied solely to purchase eligible investment securities.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P124_S2	This agreement has been amended several times and currently provides for a $40.0 million revolving credit note, bears interest at 0.25% and has a maturity date of December 1, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P124_S3	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, there were no amounts outstanding under this revolving credit note.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P125_S0	On March 4, 2008, we entered into a $35.0 million credit and security agreement with Bank of America, or BofA, for the purpose of purchasing eligible financial instruments, which include A1/P1 commercial paper, U.S. Treasury securities, GSE discount notes (as defined in the credit and security agreement) and money market funds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P125_S1	The proceeds of this note are not made generally available to us, but instead deposited in an investment account maintained by BofA and used and applied solely to purchase eligible financial instruments.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P125_S2	This agreement has been amended several times and currently provides for a $5.0 million credit line, bears interest at 1% and has a maturity date of February 28, 2012.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P125_S3	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, there were no amounts outstanding under this revolving note.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P126_S0	On August 19, 2008, we entered into a $15.0 million uncommitted facility with First Tennessee Bank for the purpose of purchasing investments, which include cash equivalents, agency securities, A1/P1 commercial paper and eligible money market funds.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P126_S1	The proceeds of this facility are not made generally available to us, but instead are held in a collateral account maintained by First Tennessee Bank.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P126_S2	This agreement has been amended several times and currently provides for a $4.0 million credit line, bears interest at 0.25% and has a maturity date of August 4, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P126_S3	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, there were no amounts outstanding under this facility.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P127_S0	On April 19, 2010, we entered into a Receivables Purchase Agreement, or RPA, which allows us to transfer an undivided interest in a designated pool of U.S. accounts receivable, on an ongoing basis, to provide collateral for borrowings up to a maximum of $55.0 million.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P127_S1	Borrowings under this arrangement generally bear interest at the commercial paper rate plus 2.75% and this agreement expires on April 18, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P127_S2	As of December 31, 2010, there were no amounts outstanding under this agreement.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P128_S0	Our wholly-owned subsidiary CBRE Capital Markets has the following warehouse lines of credit: credit agreements with JP Morgan Chase Bank, N.A., or JP Morgan, BofA, TD Bank, N.A., or TD Bank, and Kemps Landing Capital Company, LLC, or Kemps Landing, for the purpose of funding mortgage loans that will be resold and a funding arrangement with Fannie Mae for the purpose of selling a percentage of certain closed multi-family loans.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P128_S1	On November 15, 2005, CBRE Capital Markets entered into a secured credit agreement with JP Morgan to establish a warehouse line of credit.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P128_S2	Effective October 12, 2010 through January 10, 2011, the warehouse line of credit was temporarily increased from $210.0 million to $250.0 million.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P129_S0	February 1, 2011, the warehouse line of credit was temporarily increased further from $250.0 million to $300.0 million.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P129_S1	This agreement has been amended several times and effective February 1, 2011, provides for a $210.0 million senior secured revolving line of credit, bears interest at the daily Chase-London LIBOR plus 2.50% and has a maturity date of September 28, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P130_S0	On April 16, 2008, CBRE Capital Markets entered into a secured credit agreement with BofA to establish a warehouse line of credit.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P130_S1	This agreement has been amended several times and currently provides for a $125.0 million senior secured revolving line of credit, bears interest at the daily one-month LIBOR plus 2.50% with a maturity date of May 31, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P131_S0	In August 2009, CBRE Capital Markets entered into a funding arrangement with Fannie Mae under its Multifamily As Soon As Pooled Plus Agreement and its Multifamily As Soon As Pooled Sale Agreement, or ASAP Program.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P131_S1	Under the ASAP Program, CBRE Capital Markets may elect, on a transaction by transaction basis, to sell a percentage of certain closed multifamily loans to Fannie Mae on an expedited basis.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P131_S2	After all contingencies are satisfied, the ASAP Program requires that CBRE Capital Markets repurchase the interest in the multifamily loan previously sold to Fannie Mae followed by either a full delivery back to Fannie Mae via whole loan execution or a securitization into a mortgage backed security.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P131_S3	Under this agreement, the maximum outstanding balance under the ASAP Program cannot exceed $150.0 million and, between the sale date to Fannie Mae and the repurchase date by CBRE Capital Markets, the outstanding balance bears interest and is payable to Fannie Mae at the daily LIBOR rate plus 1.35% with a LIBOR floor of 0.35%.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P131_S4	Effective December 1, 2009 through January 15, 2010, the maximum outstanding balance under the ASAP Program was temporarily increased from $150.0 million to $225.0 million.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P132_S0	On December 21, 2010, CBRE Capital Markets entered into a secured credit agreement with TD Bank to establish a warehouse line of credit.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P132_S1	This agreement provides for a $75.0 million senior secured revolving line of credit, bears interest at the daily one-month LIBOR plus 2.00% with a maturity date of December 31, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P133_S0	On December 21, 2010, CBRE Capital Markets entered into an uncommitted funding arrangement with Kemps Landing providing CBRE Capital Markets with the ability to fund Freddie Mac multi-family loans.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P133_S1	Under the agreement, the maximum outstanding balance cannot exceed $200.0 million, outstanding borrowings bear interest at LIBOR plus 2.75% with a LIBOR floor of 0.25% and the agreement expires on December 20, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P133_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2010, we had a maximum of $453.8 million of warehouse lines of credit principal outstanding.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P133_S3	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, we had $453.8 million and $312.9 million of warehouse lines of credit principal outstanding, respectively, which are included in short-term borrowings in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P133_S4	Additionally, we had $485.4 million and $315.0 million of mortgage loans held for sale (warehouse receivables), which substantially represented mortgage loans funded through the lines of credit that, while committed to be purchased, had not yet been purchased as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and which are also included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P134_S0	On July 31, 2006, CBRE Capital Markets entered into a revolving credit note with JP Morgan for the purpose of purchasing qualified investment securities, which include but are not limited to U.S. Treasury and Agency securities.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P134_S1	This agreement was amended several times and provided for a $25.0 million revolving credit note, bore interest at 0.50% and had a maturity date of January 28, 2011.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P134_S2	Effective September 29, 2010, this agreement was terminated.

1138118_11_ITEM7_P136_S0	On April 30, 2007, Trammell Crow Company Acquisitions II, L.P., or Acquisitions II, a consolidated limited partnership within our Development Services segment, entered into a $100.0 million revolving credit agreement, or the WestLB Credit Agreement, with WestLB AG, as administrative agent for a lender group.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P136_S1	In April 2010, Acquisitions II opted to reduce the amount available under the WestLB Credit Agreement to $20.0 million and in October 2010, repaid the outstanding balance and the credit agreement expired.
1138118_11_ITEM7_P137_S0	Acquisitions II investors and permanent project financing, and were limited to a portion of unfunded capital commitments of certain Acquisitions II investors.
