1138118_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	Some of our offices house employees of both our Global Investment Management and Development Services segments as well as employees of our other business segments.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	Often, the employees of these segments occupy separate suites in the same building in order to operate the businesses independently with standalone offices.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	We have provided above office totals by geographic region and not listed all of our Global Investment Management and Development Services offices to avoid double counting.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P1_S1	In general, these leased offices are fully utilized.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P2_S0	The most significant terms of the leasing arrangements for our offices are the length of the lease and the rent.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P2_S1	Our leases have terms varying in duration.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P2_S2	The rent payable under our office leases varies significantly from location to location as a result of differences in prevailing commercial real estate rates in different geographic locations.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P3_S0	Our management believes that no single office lease is material to our business, results of operations or financial condition.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P3_S1	In addition, we believe there is adequate alternative office space available at acceptable rental rates to meet our needs, although adverse movements in rental rates in some markets may negatively affect our profits in those markets when we enter into new leases.
1138118_16_ITEM2_P3_S2	We do not own any of these offices.

1138118_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	We believe that any losses in excess of the amounts accrued therefor as liabilities on our financial statements are unlikely to be significant, but litigation is inherently uncertain and there is the potential for a material adverse effect on our financial statements if one or more matters are resolved in a particular period in an amount materially in excess of what we anticipated.

1138118_16_ITEM5_P1_S2	We have not declared or paid any cash dividends on any class of our common stock since our inception on February 20, 2001, and we do not anticipate declaring or paying any cash dividends on our common stock for the foreseeable future.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P1_S3	We currently intend to retain any future earnings to finance future growth and possibly reduce debt.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P1_S4	Any future determination to pay cash dividends will be at the discretion of our board of directors and will depend on our financial condition, acquisition or other opportunities to invest capital, results of operations, capital requirements and other factors that the board of directors deems relevant.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P1_S5	In addition, our ability to declare and pay cash dividends is restricted by the credit agreement governing our revolving credit facility and senior secured term loan facilities.

1138118_16_ITEM5_P15_S0	(1) On September 1, 2015, CBRE, Inc., our wholly-owned subsidiary, closed on a Stock and Asset Purchase Agreement with Johnson Controls, Inc. (JCI) to acquire JCI s Global Workplace Solutions (GWS) business (which we refer to as the GWS Acquisition).
1138118_16_ITEM5_P15_S1	The results for the year ended December 31, 2015 include the operations of GWS from September 1, 2015, the date such business was acquired.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S0	In 2011, we acquired the majority of the real estate investment management business of Netherlands-based ING Group N.V. (ING).
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S1	The acquisitions included substantially all of ING s Real Estate Investment Management (REIM) operations in Europe and Asia as well as substantially all of Clarion Real Estate Securities (CRES), its U.S.-based global real estate listed securities business (collectively referred to as ING REIM) along with certain CRES co-investments from ING and additional interests in other funds managed by ING REIM Europe and ING REIM Asia.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S2	On July 1, 2011, we completed the acquisition of CRES for $332.8 million and CRES co-investments from ING for an aggregate amount of $58.6 million.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S3	On October 3, 2011, we completed the acquisition of ING REIM Asia for $45.3 million and three ING REIM Asia co-investments from ING for an aggregate amount of $13.9 million.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S4	On October 31, 2011, we completed the acquisition of ING REIM Europe for $441.5 million and one co-investment from ING for $7.4 million.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S5	During the year ended December 31, 2012, we also funded nine additional co-investments for an aggregate amount of $34.5 million related to ING REIM Europe.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P16_S6	The results for the year ended December 31, 2011 include the operations of CRES, ING REIM Asia and ING REIM Europe from July 1, 2011, October 3, 2011 and October 31, 2011, respectively, the dates each respective business was acquired.

1138118_16_ITEM5_P18_S0	EBITDA represents earnings before net interest expense, write-off of financing costs on extinguished debt, income taxes, depreciation and amortization.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P18_S1	EBITDA is not a recognized measurement under U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and when analyzing our operating performance, investors should use EBITDA in addition to, and not as an alternative for, net income as determined in accordance with GAAP.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P18_S2	Because not all companies use identical calculations, our presentation of EBITDA may not be comparable to similarly titled measures of other companies.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P18_S3	We generally use EBITDA to evaluate operating performance and for other discretionary purposes, and we believe that this measure provides a more complete understanding of ongoing operations and enhances comparability of current results to prior periods.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P18_S4	We further believe that investors may find EBITDA useful in evaluating our operating performance compared to that of other companies in our industry because EBITDA calculations generally eliminate the effects of acquisitions, which would include impairment charges of goodwill and intangibles created from acquisitions, the effects of financings and income taxes and the accounting effects of capital spending.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P19_S0	EBITDA may vary for different companies for reasons unrelated to overall operating performance.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P20_S0	EBITDA is not intended to be a measure of free cash flow for our discretionary use because it does not consider certain cash requirements such as tax and debt service payments.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P20_S1	EBITDA may also differ from the amount calculated under similarly titled definitions in our debt instruments, which amounts are further adjusted to reflect certain other cash and non-cash charges and are used by us to determine compliance with financial covenants therein and our ability to engage in certain activities, such as incurring additional debt and making certain restricted payments.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P21_S0	EBITDA is calculated as follows (dollars in thousands):
1138118_16_ITEM5_P22_S0	In the third quarter of 2015, we elected to early adopt the provisions of Accounting Standards Update (ASU) 2015-03, Interest Imputation of Interest (Subtopic 835-30): Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P22_S1	This ASU requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability instead of separately being recorded in other assets.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P22_S2	As of December 31, 2014, deferred financing costs totaling $25.6 million have been reclassified from other assets and netted against the related debt liabilities to conform with the current year presentation.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P22_S3	See Deferred Financing Costs discussion within Note 2 of our Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Annual Report.
1138118_16_ITEM5_P22_S4	Amounts for 2011, 2012 and 2013 have not been reclassified to conform with the current year presentation.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	We are the world s largest commercial real estate services and investment firm, based on 2015 revenue, with leading full-service operations in major metropolitan areas throughout the world.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S1	We offer a full range of services to occupiers, owners, lenders and investors in office, retail, industrial, multifamily and other types of commercial real estate.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S2	As of December 31, 2015, excluding independent affiliates, we operated in more than 400 offices worldwide with more than 70,000 employees providing commercial real estate services under the CBRE brand name, investment management services under the CBRE Global Investors brand name and development services under the Trammell Crow Company brand name.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S3	Our business is focused on several competencies, including commercial property, corporate facilities, project and transaction management, tenant/occupier and property/agency leasing, capital markets solutions (property sales, commercial mortgage origination, sales and servicing, and structured finance) real estate investment management, valuation, development services and proprietary research.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S4	We generate revenue from both management fees (large multi-year portfolio and per-project contracts) and from commissions on transactions.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S5	We have been included in the Fortune 500 since 2008 and among the Fortune Most Admired Companies in the real estate sector for four consecutive years.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S6	In 2015, we were ranked second among all companies on the Barron s 500, which evaluates companies on growth and financial performance.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P0_S7	Additionally, the International Association of Outsourcing Professionals (IAOP) has ranked us among the top few outsourcing service providers across all industries for five consecutive years.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States, which require management to make estimates and assumptions that affect reported amounts.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	The estimates and assumptions are based on historical experience and on other factors that management believes to be reasonable.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P1_S2	Actual results may differ from those estimates.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P1_S3	We believe that the following critical accounting policies represent the areas where more significant judgments and estimates are used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P1_S4	In order for us to recognize revenue, four basic criteria must be met:
1138118_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our revenue recognition policies are consistent with these criteria.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The judgments involved in revenue recognition include understanding the complex terms of agreements and determining the appropriate time to recognize revenue for each transaction based on such terms.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	Each transaction is evaluated to determine: (i) at what point in time revenue is earned; (ii) whether contingencies exist that impact the timing of recognition of revenue; and (iii) how and when such contingencies will be resolved.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	The timing of revenue recognition could vary if different judgments were made.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P3_S3	Our revenues subject to the most judgment are brokerage commission revenue and incentive-based management and development fees.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P3_S4	For a detailed discussion of our revenue recognition policies, see the Revenue Recognition section within Note 2 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K (this Annual Report).
1138118_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	In establishing the appropriate provisions for trade receivables, we make assumptions with respect to future collectability.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our assumptions are based on an assessment of a customer s credit quality as well as subjective factors and trends, including the aging of receivables balances.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	outstanding trade accounts receivable amounts that are more than 180 days overdue are evaluated for collectability and fully provided for if deemed uncollectible.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	Historically, our credit losses have generally been insignificant.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	However, estimating losses requires significant judgment, and conditions may change or new information may become known after any periodic evaluation.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	As a result, actual credit losses may differ from our estimates.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets Our acquisitions require the application of purchase accounting, which results in tangible and identifiable intangible assets and liabilities of the acquired entity being recorded at fair value.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	The difference between the purchase price and the fair value of net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	In determining the fair values of assets and liabilities acquired in a business combination, we use a variety of valuation methods including present value, depreciated replacement cost, market values (where available) and selling prices less costs to dispose.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	We are responsible for determining the valuation of assets and liabilities and for the allocation of purchase price to assets acquired and liabilities assumed.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Assumptions must often be made in determining fair values, particularly where observable market values do not exist.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P10_S1	Assumptions may include discount rates, growth rates, cost of capital, royalty rates, tax rates and remaining useful lives.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P10_S2	These assumptions can have a significant impact on the value of identifiable assets and accordingly can impact the value of goodwill recorded.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P10_S3	Different assumptions could result in different values being attributed to assets and liabilities.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P10_S4	Since these values impact the amount of annual depreciation and amortization expense, different assumptions could also impact our statement of operations and could impact the results of future asset impairment reviews.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	We are required to test goodwill and other intangible assets deemed to have indefinite useful lives for impairment at least annually or more often if circumstances or events indicate a change in the impairment status.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	The goodwill impairment analysis is a two-step process.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	The first step used to identify potential impairment involves comparing each reporting unit s estimated fair value to its carrying value, including goodwill.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	We use a discounted cash flow approach to estimate the fair value of our reporting units.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	Management judgment is required in developing the assumptions for the discounted cash flow model.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	These assumptions include revenue growth rates, profit margin percentages, discount rates, etc.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	If the estimated fair value of a reporting unit exceeds its carrying value, goodwill is considered to not be impaired.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	If the carrying value exceeds estimated fair value, there is an indication of potential impairment and the second step is performed to measure the amount of impairment.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	The second step of the process involves the calculation of an implied fair value of goodwill for each reporting unit for which step one indicated impairment.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	The implied fair value of goodwill is determined by measuring the excess of the estimated fair value of the reporting unit as calculated in step one, over the estimated fair values of the individual assets, liabilities and identifiable intangibles as if the reporting unit was being acquired in a business combination.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	Due to the many variables inherent in the estimation of a business s fair value and the relative size of our goodwill, if different assumptions and estimates were used, it could have an adverse effect on our impairment analysis.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2013, we recorded a non-amortizable intangible asset impairment of $98.1 million in our Global Investment Management segment.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	This non-cash write-off was related to a decrease in value of our open-end funds, primarily in Europe.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P16_S2	For additional information on goodwill and intangible asset impairment testing, see Notes 2, 5 and 8 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Annual Report.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	Income Taxes Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method in accordance with the Accounting for Income Taxes , Topic of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, or FASB, Accounting Standards Codification, or ASC, (Topic 740).
1138118_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	differences between the financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry forwards.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P18_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured by applying enacted tax rates and laws and are released in the years in which the temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P18_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Valuation allowances are provided against deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update, or ASU, 2015-17, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes (ASU 2015-17).
1138118_16_ITEM7_P20_S1	This ASU requires the offset of all deferred tax assets and liabilities, including valuation allowances, for each tax-paying jurisdiction within each tax-paying component.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	The net deferred tax must be presented as a single noncurrent amount.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	ASU 2015-17 is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2016, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	Entities may elect to use either a prospective or retrospective transition method.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P23_S1	We elected to early adopt the provisions of ASU 2015-17 during the fourth quarter of 2015 and balance sheet amounts as of December 31, 2014 have been reclassified to conform with the current period presentation.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	As of December 31, 2014, $205.9 million of current deferred tax assets were reclassified to long term deferred tax assets.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	Accounting for tax positions requires judgments, including estimating reserves for potential uncertainties.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	We also assess our ability to utilize tax attributes, including those in the form of carryforwards, for which the benefits have already been reflected in the financial statements.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	We do not record valuation allowances for deferred tax assets that we believe will be realized in future periods.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S3	While we believe the resulting tax balances as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 are appropriately accounted for in accordance with Topic 740, as applicable, the ultimate outcome of such matters could result in favorable or unfavorable adjustments to our consolidated financial statements and such adjustments could be material.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S4	Our foreign subsidiaries have accumulated $1.4 billion of undistributed earnings for which we have not recorded a deferred tax liability.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S5	Although tax liabilities might result from dividends being paid out of these earnings, or as a result of a sale or liquidation of non-U.S. subsidiaries, these earnings are permanently reinvested outside of the United States and we do not have any plans to repatriate them or to sell or liquidate any of our non-U.S. subsidiaries.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S6	To the extent that we are able to repatriate earnings in a tax efficient manner, we would be required to accrue and pay U.S. taxes to repatriate these funds, net of foreign tax credits.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S7	Determining our tax liability upon repatriation is not practicable.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S8	Cash and cash equivalents owned by non-U.S. subsidiaries totaled $315.5 million at December 31, 2015.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S9	In 2013, we repatriated $196.2 million.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S10	Tax benefits associated with the release of valuation allowances on foreign tax credits of $14.5 million and $4.9 million were recorded in 2013 and 2014, respectively.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S11	See Note 13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Annual Report for further information regarding income taxes.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P25_S12	New Accounting Pronouncements See New Accounting Pronouncements section within Note 2 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements set forth in Item 8 of this Annual Report.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	Items Affecting Comparability Macroeconomic Conditions Economic trends and government policies affect global and regional commercial real estate markets as well as our operations directly.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	These include: overall economic activity and employment growth; interest rate levels and changes in interest rates; the cost and availability of credit; and the impact of tax and regulatory policies.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	employment levels, decreasing demand for commercial real estate, falling real estate values, disruption to the global capital or credit markets, or the public perception that any of these events may occur, will negatively affect the performance of our business.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Compensation is our largest expense and the sales and leasing professionals in our advisory services business generally are paid on a commission and/or bonus basis that correlates with their revenue production.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P27_S2	As a result, the negative effect of difficult market conditions on our operating margins is partially mitigated by the inherent variability of our compensation cost structure.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P27_S3	In addition, when negative economic conditions have been particularly severe, we have moved decisively to lower operating expenses to improve financial performance, and then have restored certain expenses as economic conditions improved.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P27_S4	Nevertheless, adverse global and regional economic trends could pose significant risks to the performance of our operations and our financial condition.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Commercial real estate markets have recovered over the past several years, along with the steady improvement in global economic activity, most particularly in the United States.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	Since 2010, increased U.S. property sales activity has been sustained by gradually improving market fundamentals, low-cost credit availability and increased global and domestic capital flows.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	During this time, U.S. leasing markets have been marked by increased demand for space, falling vacancies and higher rents.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	European economies began to emerge from recession in 2013, with most countries returning to positive, albeit modest, economic growth.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	Reflecting the macro environment, leasing markets in most of Europe were slow to recover, but improved significantly in 2015.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	Buoyed by low-cost credit and continued capital flows, Europe saw increased property sales activity in 2015, with higher volumes occurring across more markets, particularly on the continent.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	In Asia Pacific, the performance of real estate leasing and investment markets has varied from country to country amid slowing economic growth.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	Strength in Australia has generally compensated for slower activity elsewhere in the region.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P30_S2	In addition, increasingly, local capital has been migrating to other parts of the world.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P30_S3	Real estate investment management and property development markets have been generally favorable with abundant debt and equity capital flows into commercial real estate.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P30_S4	However, real estate equity securities markets were adversely affected in 2015 by investor concerns about rising interest rates.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	The performance of our global sales, leasing, investment management and development services operations depends on sustained economic growth and strong job creation; stable, healthy global credit markets; and continued positive business and investor sentiment.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	Effects of Acquisitions The Company historically has made significant use of strategic acquisitions to add new service competencies, to increase our scale within existing competencies and to expand our presence in various geographic regions around the world.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	On September 1, 2015, CBRE, Inc., our wholly-owned subsidiary, closed on a Stock and Asset Purchase Agreement (the Purchase Agreement) with Johnson Controls, Inc. (JCI) to acquire JCI s Global Workplace Solutions (GWS) business (which we refer to as the GWS Acquisition).
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	The acquired GWS business is a market-leading provider of integrated facilities management solutions for major occupiers of commercial real estate and has significant operations around the world.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S2	The purchase price was $1.475 billion, paid in cash, with adjustments for working capital and other items.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S3	We completed the GWS Acquisition in order to advance our strategy of delivering globally integrated services to major occupiers in our Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific segments.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S4	We merged the acquired GWS business with our existing occupier outsourcing business line, and the new combined business adopted the Global Workplace Solutions name.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P32_S5	Strategic in-fill acquisitions have also played a key role in expanding our geographic coverage and broadening and strengthening our service offerings.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	specialty firms that complement our existing platform within a region, or independent affiliates in which, in some cases, we held a small equity interest.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	During 2015, we completed eight in-fill acquisitions, including a Seattle-based leader in capital markets services for affordable housing, a Texas-based commercial real estate firm specializing in retail services, an energy management specialist based in Brookfield, Wisconsin, a Chicago-based location data analytics firm, one of the leading retail real estate services firms in the midwestern United States, an advisory, consulting and research firm specializing in the Canadian hospitality and tourism industries and our former independent affiliate companies in Columbia, South Carolina, and Memphis, Tennessee.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	During 2014, we completed 11 in-fill acquisitions, including our former independent affiliate companies in Thailand, Greenville, South Carolina, Louisville, Kentucky and Oklahoma City and Tulsa, Oklahoma, a commercial real estate service provider in Chicago, a New York-based valuation and advisory business, a technical real estate consulting firm based in Germany, a consulting and advisory firm in the U.S. hotels sector, a shopping center management, leasing and consulting company in Switzerland and project management companies in Germany and Australia.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	Although we believe that strategic acquisitions can significantly decrease the cost, time and commitment of management resources necessary to attain a meaningful competitive position within targeted markets or to expand our presence within our current markets, in general, most acquisitions will initially have an adverse impact on our operating and net income.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	The adverse impact is a result of transaction-related expenditures, which include severance, lease termination, transaction and deferred financing costs, among others, and the charges and costs of integrating the acquired business and its financial and accounting systems into our own.
1138118_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	In addition, our acquisition structures often include deferred and/or contingent purchase price payments in future periods that are subject to the passage of time or achievement of certain performance metrics and other conditions.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULES All other schedules are omitted because they are either not applicable, not required or the information required is included in the Consolidated Financial Statements, including the notes thereto.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM The Board of Directors and Stockholders CBRE Group, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of CBRE Group, Inc. (the Company) and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, cash flows and equity for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	In connection with our audits of the consolidated financial statements, we also have audited the related financial statement schedule.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S2	We also have audited the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S3	The Company s management is responsible for these consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting, and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting .
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S4	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedules and an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audits.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S5	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S6	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S7	Our audits of the consolidated financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S8	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S9	Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P1_S10	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P2_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P2_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	CBRE Group, Inc. acquired the Global Workplace Solutions business during 2015 (the Acquired Business) as defined in Note 3 to the consolidated financial statements, and management excluded from its assessment of the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, the Acquired Business s internal control over financial reporting associated with total assets of $2.3 billion and total revenues of $982.0 million included in the consolidated financial statements of CBRE Group, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	Our audit of internal control over financial reporting of the Company also excluded an evaluation of the internal control over financial reporting of the Acquired Business.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of CBRE Group, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P4_S1	Also in our opinion, the related financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P4_S2	Also in our opinion, CBRE Group, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.

1138118_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1138118_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
