1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S0	Our Global Investment Management segment earns performance-based incentive fees with regard to many of its investments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S1	Such revenue is recognized at the end of the measurement periods when the conditions of the applicable incentive fee arrangements have been satisfied and following the expiration of any potential claw back provision.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S2	With many of these investments, our Global Investment Management professionals have participation interests in such incentive fees, which are commonly referred to as carried interest.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S3	This carried interest expense is generally accrued for based upon the probability of such performance-based incentive fees being earned over the related vesting period.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S4	In addition, our Global Investment Management segment also earns success-based transaction fees with regard to buying or selling properties on behalf of certain funds and separate accounts.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P41_S5	Such revenue is recognized at the completion of a successful transaction and is not subject to any claw back provision.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P42_S0	Appraisal fees are recorded after services have been rendered.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P42_S1	and we have no significant remaining obligations for performance in connection with the transaction, while loan servicing fees are recorded in revenue as monthly principal and interest payments are collected from mortgagors.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P42_S2	Other commissions, consulting fees and referral fees are recorded as revenue at the time the related services have been performed, unless future contingencies exist.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P43_S0	Development services and project management services generate fees from development and construction management projects.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P43_S1	Most development and construction management and project management assignments are subject to agreements that describe the calculation of fees and when we earn such fees.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P43_S2	The earnings terms of these agreements dictate when we recognize the related revenue.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P43_S3	Generally, development fees are recognized based on the lower of the amount billed or the amount determined on a straight-line basis over the development period.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P44_S0	We may earn incentive fees for project management services based upon achievement of certain performance criteria as set forth in the project management services agreement.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P44_S1	Incentive development fees are recognized when quantitative criteria have been met (such as specified leasing, budget or time-based targets) or for those incentive fees based on qualitative criteria, upon approval of the fee by our clients.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P44_S2	Certain incentive development fees allow us to share in the fair value of the developed real estate asset above cost.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P44_S3	This sharing creates additional revenue potential to us with no exposure to loss other than opportunity cost.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P44_S4	We recognize such fees when the specified target is attained and fees are deemed collectible.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P45_S0	We record deferred income to the extent that cash payments have been received in accordance with the terms of underlying agreements, but such amounts have not yet met the criteria for revenue recognition in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P45_S1	We recognize such revenues when the appropriate criteria are met.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P46_S0	In establishing the appropriate provisions for trade receivables, we make assumptions with respect to future collectability.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P46_S1	Our assumptions are based on an assessment of a customer s credit quality as well as subjective factors and trends, including the aging of receivables balances.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P46_S2	In addition to these assessments, in general, outstanding trade accounts receivable amounts that are more than 180 days overdue are evaluated for collectability and fully provided for if deemed uncollectible.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P47_S0	Historically, our credit losses have generally been insignificant.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P47_S1	However, estimating losses requires significant judgment, and conditions may change or new information may become known after any periodic evaluation.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P47_S2	As a result, actual credit losses may differ from our estimates.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P48_S0	The costs of business promotion and advertising are expensed as incurred.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P48_S1	Business promotion and advertising costs of $63.1 million, $65.8 million and $62.7 million were included in operating, administrative and other expenses for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P49_S0	The financial statements of subsidiaries located outside the U.S. are generally measured using the local currency as the functional currency.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P49_S1	The assets and liabilities of these subsidiaries are translated at the rates of exchange at the balance sheet date, and income and expenses are translated at the average monthly rate.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P49_S2	The resulting translation adjustments are included in the accumulated other comprehensive loss component of equity.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P49_S3	Gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are included in the results of operations.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P50_S0	As required by FASB ASC Topic 815 Derivatives and Hedging , we record all derivatives on the balance sheet at fair value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P50_S1	We do not net derivatives on our balance sheet.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P50_S2	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivatives depends on the intended use of the derivative, whether we have elected to designate a derivative in a hedging relationship and apply hedge accounting and whether the hedging relationship has satisfied the criteria necessary to apply hedge accounting.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P51_S0	Derivatives designated and qualifying as a hedge of the exposure to changes in the fair value of an asset, liability, or firm commitment attributable to a particular risk, such as interest rate risk, are considered fair value hedges.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P51_S1	Derivatives designated and qualifying as a hedge of the exposure to variability in expected future cash flows, or other types of forecasted transactions, are considered cash flow hedges.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P51_S2	Derivatives may also be designated as hedges of the foreign currency exposure of a net investment in a foreign operation.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P52_S0	Hedge accounting generally provides for the matching of the timing of gain or loss recognition on the hedging instrument with the recognition of the changes in the fair value of the hedged asset or liability that are attributable to the hedged risk in a fair value hedge or the earnings effect of the hedged forecasted transactions in a cash flow hedge.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P53_S0	We may enter into derivative contracts that are intended to economically hedge certain of our risk, even though hedge accounting does not apply or we elect not to apply hedge accounting.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P53_S1	In all cases, we view derivative financial instruments as a risk management tool and, accordingly, do not use derivatives for trading or speculative purposes.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P54_S0	Comprehensive Income Comprehensive income consists of net income and other comprehensive income (loss).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P54_S1	In the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, accumulated other comprehensive loss consists of foreign currency translation adjustments, fees associated with the termination of interest rate swaps, unrealized gains (losses) on interest rate swaps, unrealized holding gains (losses) on available for sale securities and pension liability adjustments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P54_S2	Foreign currency translation adjustments exclude any income tax effect given that earnings of non-U.S. subsidiaries are deemed to be reinvested for an indefinite period of time (see Note 14).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P55_S0	Marketable Securities We account for investments in marketable debt and equity securities in accordance with the Investments Debt and Equity Securities Topic of the FASB ASC (Topic 320).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P55_S1	We determine the appropriate classification of debt and equity securities at the time of purchase and reevaluate such designation as of each balance sheet date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P56_S0	Marketable securities we acquire with the intent to generate a profit from short-term movements in market prices are classified as trading securities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P56_S1	Debt securities are classified as held to maturity when we have the positive intent and ability to hold the securities to maturity.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P56_S2	Marketable equity and debt securities not classified as trading or held to maturity are classified as available for sale.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P57_S0	Trading securities are carried at their fair value with realized and unrealized gains and losses included in net income.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P57_S1	Available for sale securities are carried at their fair value and any difference between cost and fair value is recorded as unrealized gain or loss, net of income taxes, and is reported as accumulated other comprehensive loss in the consolidated statement of equity.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P58_S0	Premiums and discounts are recognized in interest using the effective interest method.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P58_S1	Realized gains and losses and declines in value expected to be other-than-temporary on available for sale securities have not been significant.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P59_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P59_S1	Interest and dividends on securities classified as available for sale are included in interest income.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P60_S0	For investments classified as available for sale, we assess impairment at the individual security level.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P60_S1	An investment is impaired if the fair value of the investment is less than its amortized cost basis.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P60_S2	When an impairment exists, we assess whether such impairment is temporary or other-than-temporary.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P60_S3	We review the volatility and intended holding period of our investments and also determine if we believe that there is a reasonable possibility that the value would be recovered over the intended holding period.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P60_S4	Based on our review, we did not record any significant other-than-temporary impairment losses during the years ending December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P61_S0	Our wholly-owned subsidiary CBRE Capital Markets, Inc. (CBRE Capital Markets) is a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) approved Multifamily Program Plus Seller/Servicer and an approved Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) Aggregation and Negotiated Transaction Seller/Servicer.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P61_S1	In addition, CBRE Capital Markets wholly-owned subsidiary CBRE Multifamily Capital, Inc. (CBRE MCI) is an approved Fannie Mae Delegated Underwriting and Servicing (DUS) Seller/Servicer and CBRE Capital Markets wholly-owned subsidiary CBRE HMF is a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) approved Non-Supervised Federal Housing Authority (FHA) Title II Mortgagee, an approved Multifamily Accelerated Processing (MAP) lender and an approved Government National Mortgage Association (Ginnie Mae) issuer of mortgage-backed securities (MBS).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P62_S0	Under these arrangements, before loans are originated through proceeds from warehouse lines of credit, we obtain either a contractual loan purchase commitment from either Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae or a confirmed forward trade commitment for the issuance and purchase of a Fannie Mae or Ginnie Mae MBS that will be secured by the loans.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P62_S1	The warehouse lines of credit are generally repaid within a one-month period when Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae buys the loans or upon settlement of the Fannie Mae or Ginnie Mae MBS, while we retain the servicing rights.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P63_S0	Loans are funded at the prevailing market rates.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P64_S0	We elect the fair value option for all warehouse receivables.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P64_S1	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, all of the warehouse receivables included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets were either under commitment to be purchased by Freddie Mac or had confirmed forward trade commitments for the issuance and purchase of Fannie Mae or Ginnie Mae mortgage-backed securities that will be secured by the underlying loans.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P65_S0	In connection with the origination and sale of mortgage loans with servicing rights retained, we record servicing assets or liabilities based on the fair value of the mortgage servicing rights on the date the loans are sold.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P66_S0	Our mortgage service rights (MSRs) are initially recorded at fair value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P66_S1	Subsequent to the initial recording, MSRs are amortized and carried at the lower of amortized cost or fair value in other intangible assets in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P66_S2	They are amortized in proportion to and over the estimated period that net servicing income is expected to be received based on projections and timing of estimated future net cash flows.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P66_S3	Our initial recording of MSRs at their fair value resulted in net gains, as the fair value of servicing contracts that result in MSR assets exceeded the fair value of servicing contracts that result in MSR liabilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P66_S4	The net assets and net gains are presented in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P67_S0	The amount of MSRs recognized during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 was as follows (dollars in thousands):
1138118_18_ITEM8_P68_S0	MSRs do not actively trade in an open market with readily available observable prices; therefore, fair value is determined based on certain assumptions and judgments, including the estimation of the present value of future cash flows realized from servicing the underlying mortgage loans.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P68_S1	Management s assumptions include the benefits of servicing (servicing fee income and interest on escrow deposits), inflation, the cost of servicing, prepayment rates, delinquencies, discount rates and the estimated life of servicing cash flows.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P68_S2	The assumptions used are subject to change based on management s judgments and estimates of changes in future cash flows and interest rates, among other things.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P68_S3	The key assumptions used during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015 in measuring fair value were as follows:
1138118_18_ITEM8_P69_S0	The estimated fair value of our MSRs was $446.3 million and $375.5 million as of December 31, 2017 and 2016, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P69_S1	Impairment is evaluated through a comparison of the carrying amount and fair value of the MSRs, and recognized with the establishment of a valuation allowance.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P69_S2	We did not incur any impairment charges related to our MSRs during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 or 2015.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P69_S3	No valuation allowance was created previously and we did not record a valuation allowance for MSRs in 2017 or 2016.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P69_S4	Included in revenue in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations are contractually specified servicing fees from loans serviced for others of $144.2 million, $115.3 million and $92.0 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively, and prepayment fees/late fees/ancillary income earned from loans serviced for others of $13.2 million, $7.2 million and $8.4 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P70_S0	Accounting for Broker Draws As part of our recruitment efforts relative to new U.S. brokers, we offer a transitional broker draw arrangement.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P70_S1	Our broker draw arrangements generally last until such time as a broker s pipeline of business is sufficient to allow him or her to earn sustainable commissions.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P71_S0	This program is intended to provide the broker with a minimal amount of cash flow to allow adequate time for his or her training as well as time for him or her to develop business relationships.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P71_S1	Similar to traditional salaries, the broker draws are paid irrespective of the actual revenues generated by the broker.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P71_S2	Often these broker draws represent the only form of compensation received by the broker.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P71_S3	Furthermore, it is not our general policy to pursue collection of unearned broker draws paid under this arrangement.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P71_S4	As a result, we have concluded that broker draws are economically equivalent to salaries paid and accordingly charge them to compensation expense as incurred.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P72_S0	The broker is also entitled to earn a commission on completed revenue transactions.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P72_S1	This amount is calculated as the commission that would have been payable under our full commission program, less any amounts previously paid to the broker in the form of a draw.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P73_S0	Stock-Based Compensation We account for all employee awards under the fair value recognition provisions of the Compensation Stock Compensation Topic of the FASB ASC (Topic 718).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P73_S1	Topic 718 requires the measurement of compensation cost at the grant date, based upon the estimated fair value of the award, and requires amortization of the related expense over the employee s requisite service period.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P74_S0	In the third quarter of 2016, we elected to early adopt the provisions of ASU 2016-09, Compensation - Stock Compensation (Topic 718): Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting, which required us to reflect any adjustments as of January 1, 2016.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P75_S0	ASU 2016-09 permitted companies to make an accounting policy election to either estimate forfeitures on share-based payment awards, as previously required, or to recognize forfeitures as they occur.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P75_S1	We elected to change our accounting policy to recognize forfeitures when they occur and the impact of this change in accounting policy was recorded as a $3.3 million cumulative effect adjustment to accumulated earnings as of January 1, 2016.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P75_S2	See Note 13 for additional information on our stock-based compensation plans.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P76_S0	Basic income per share attributable to CBRE Group, Inc. is computed by dividing net income attributable to CBRE Group, Inc. shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during each period.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P76_S1	The computation of diluted income per share attributable to CBRE Group, Inc. generally further assumes the dilutive effect of potential common shares, which include stock options and certain contingently issuable shares.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P76_S2	Contingently issuable shares consist of non-vested stock awards.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P77_S0	Income Taxes Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method in accordance with the Accounting for Income Taxes Topic of the FASB ASC (Topic 740).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P78_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on temporary differences between the financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities and operating loss and tax credit carry forwards.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P78_S1	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured by applying enacted tax rates and laws and are released in the years in which the temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P78_S2	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P79_S0	Valuation allowances are provided against deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax asset will not be realized.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P80_S0	See Note 14 for additional information on income taxes, including a discussion of the impact of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the Tax Act), which was signed into law on December 22, 2017.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S0	Self-Insurance Our wholly-owned captive insurance company, which is subject to applicable insurance rules and regulations, insures our exposure related to workers compensation insurance, general liability insurance and automotive insurance for our U.S. operations risk on a primary basis and we purchase excess coverage from unrelated insurance carriers.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S1	The captive insurance company also insures primary risk relating to professional indemnity claims globally.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S2	Given the nature of these types of claims, it may take several years for resolution and determination of the cost of these claims.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S3	We are required to estimate the cost of these claims in our financial statements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S4	The estimates that we utilize to record our potential losses on claims are inherently subjective, and actual claims could differ from amounts recorded, which could result in increased or decreased expense in future periods.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P81_S5	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, our reserves for claims under these insurance programs were $93.7 million and $80.6 million, respectively, of which $2.8 million and $1.7 million, respectively, represented our estimated current liabilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P82_S0	The FASB has recently issued five ASUs related to revenue recognition ( new revenue recognition guidance ), all of which will become effective for the company on January 1, 2018.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P82_S1	The ASUs issued are: (1) in May 2014, ASU 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606); (2) i n March 2016, ASU 2016-08, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Principal versus Agent Considerations (Reporting Revenue Gross versus Net); (3) in April 2016, ASU 2016-10, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Identifying Performance Obligations and Licensing; (4) in May 2016, ASU 2016-12, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606): Narrow-scope Improvements and Practical Expedients; and (5) in December 2016, ASU 2016-20, Technical Corrections and Improvements to Topic 606, Revenue From Contracts with Customers.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S0	ASU 2014-09 requires an entity to recognize the amount of revenue to which it expects to be entitled for the transfer of promised goods or services to customers and will replace most existing revenue recognition guidance under GAAP.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S1	The ASU also requires entities to disclose both quantitative and qualitative information to enable users of financial statements to understand the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S2	This ASU permits the use of either the retrospective or cumulative effect transition method.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S3	ASU 2016-08 clarifies the implementation guidance on principal versus agent considerations.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S4	ASU 2016-10 clarifies guidance related to identifying performance obligations and licensing implementation guidance contained in ASU 2014-09.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S5	ASU 2016-12 clarifies guidance in certain narrow areas and adds some practical expedients.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S6	ASU 2016-20 also clarifies guidance in certain narrow areas and adds optional exemptions to certain disclosure requirements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S7	We plan to adopt the new revenue recognition guidance in the first quarter of 2018 using the retrospective transition method.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S8	Based on our assessment, the impact of the application of the new revenue recognition guidance will result in an acceleration of some revenues that are based, in part, on future contingent events.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S9	For example, some leasing commission revenues in various countries where we operate will be recognized earlier.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S10	Under current GAAP, a portion of these lease commission revenues are deferred until a future contingency is resolved (e.g., tenant move-in or payment of first month s rent).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S11	Under the new revenue guidance, the company s performance obligation will be typically satisfied at lease signing and therefore the portion of the commission that is contingent on a future event will likely be recognized earlier if deemed not subject to significant reversal.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P83_S12	We expect the earlier recognition of these revenues to result in an increase in total assets and liabilities to reflect contract assets and accrued commissions payable.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P84_S0	We have evaluated the impact of the updated principal versus agent guidance on our consolidated financial statements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P84_S1	Under existing GAAP, certain of our facilities and project management contracts are accounted for on a net basis because the contracts include provisions such as pay when paid that mitigate payment risk with respect to services provided by third parties to our clients.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P84_S2	Under the updated guidance, control of the services before transfer to the client is the primary factor in determining principal versus agent assessments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P84_S3	Payment risk will no longer be a determining factor under ASC Topic 606.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P85_S0	Accordingly, under the new guidance, we will account for the cost of services provided by third parties and the related reimbursement revenue on a gross basis.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P85_S1	Under the retrospective method, based upon our evaluations which are not yet complete, we estimate that the 2016 and 2017 consolidated statements of operations will reflect approximately $4 to $5 billion of additional revenue and cost of services as a result of this change, with no impact on profitability.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P86_S0	(Subtopic 825-10): Recognition and Measurement of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P86_S1	This ASU will significantly change the income statement impact of equity investments and the recognition of changes in fair value of financial liabilities when the fair value option is elected.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P86_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those years, beginning after December 15, 2017.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P86_S3	Early adoption is not permitted, except for the provisions related to the recognition of changes in fair value of financial liabilities when the fair value option is elected.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P86_S4	We do not believe the adoption of ASU 2016-01 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P87_S0	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P87_S1	This ASU requires lessees to recognize most leases on the balance sheet as liabilities, with corresponding right-of-use assets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P87_S2	For income statement recognition purposes, leases will be classified as either a finance or operating lease in a manner similar to the requirements under the current lease accounting literature, but without relying upon the bright-line tests.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P87_S3	This ASU is effective for annual periods in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018 and mandates a modified retrospective transition method for all entities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P87_S4	We plan to adopt ASU 2016-02 in the first quarter of 2019 and are currently continuing to evaluate the magnitude of its impact on our consolidated financial statements by reviewing our existing lease contracts and service contracts that may include embedded leases.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P88_S0	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, Financial Instruments Credit Losses (Topic 326): Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P88_S1	This ASU is intended to improve financial reporting by requiring timelier recording of credit losses on loans and other financial instruments held by financial institutions and other organizations.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P88_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P89_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU 2016-13 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P90_S0	In August 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-15, Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Classification of Certain Cash Receipts and Cash Payments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P90_S1	This ASU addresses eight specific cash flow issues with the objective of reducing the existing diversity in practice.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P90_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P90_S3	At this point in time, we do not believe the adoption of ASU 2016-15 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P91_S0	In October 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-16, Income Taxes (Topic 740): Intra-Entity Transfers of Assets Other Than Inventory.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P91_S1	This ASU requires an entity to recognize the income tax consequences of an intra-entity transfer of an asset other than inventory when the transfer occurs.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P91_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P91_S3	At this point in time, we do not believe the adoption of ASU 2016-16 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P92_S0	In November 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-18, Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230): Restricted Cash.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P92_S1	This ASU requires that a statement of cash flows explain the change during the period in the total of cash, cash equivalents, and amounts generally described as restricted cash or restricted cash equivalents.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P92_S2	As a result, amounts generally described as restricted cash and restricted cash equivalents should be included with cash and cash equivalents when reconciling the beginning-of-period and end-of-period total amounts shown on the statement of cash flows.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P92_S3	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P92_S4	At this point in time, we do not believe the adoption of ASU 2016-18 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P93_S0	In January 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-04, Intangibles Goodwill and Other (Topic 350): Simplifying the Test for Goodwill Impairment.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P93_S1	This ASU eliminates Step 2 from the goodwill impairment test.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P93_S2	This ASU also eliminates the requirements for any reporting unit with a zero or negative carrying amount to perform a qualitative assessment.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P93_S3	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P93_S4	We are evaluating the effect that ASU 2017-04 will have on our goodwill assessment process, but do not believe the adoption of ASU 2017-04 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P94_S0	In February 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-05, Other Income Gains and Losses from the Derecognition of Nonfinancial Assets (Subtopic 610-20): Clarifying the Scope of Asset Derecognition Guidance and Accounting for Partial Sales of Nonfinancial Assets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P94_S1	This ASU clarifies that a financial asset is within the scope of Subtopic 610-20 if it meets the definition of an in substance nonfinancial asset and also defines the term in substance nonfinancial asset.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P94_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2017, and interim periods within those years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P94_S3	At this point in time, we do not believe the adoption of ASU 2017-05 will have a material impact on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P95_S0	In March 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-08, Receivables Nonrefundable Fees and Other Costs (Subtopic 310-20), Premium Amortization on Purchased Callable Debt Securities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P95_S1	This ASU requires the premium to be amortized to the earliest call date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P95_S2	This ASU does not require an accounting change for securities held at a discount; the discount continues to be amortized to maturity.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P95_S3	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P96_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU 2017-08 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P97_S0	In August 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-12, Derivatives and Hedging (Topic 815): Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P97_S1	This ASU refines and expands hedge accounting for both financial and commodity risks.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P97_S2	This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, and interim periods within those years, with early adoption permitted.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P98_S0	We are evaluating the effect that ASU 2017-12 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P98_S1	Certain reclassifications have been made to the 2016 and 2015 financial statements to conform with the 2017 presentation.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S0	On September 1, 2015, CBRE, Inc., our wholly-owned subsidiary, pursuant to a Stock and Asset Purchase Agreement with JCI, acquired JCI s GWS business (we refer to as the GWS Acquisition).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S1	The acquired JCI-GWS business was a market-leading provider of integrated facilities management solutions for major occupiers of commercial real estate and had significant operations around the world.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S2	The purchase price was $1.475 billion, paid in cash, plus adjustments totaling $46.5 million for working capital and other items.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S3	We completed the GWS Acquisition in order to advance our strategy of delivering globally integrated services to major occupiers in our Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific segments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S4	We merged the acquired JCI-GWS business with our existing occupier outsourcing business line, and the new combined business adopted the Global Workplace Solutions name.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S5	We financed the transaction with: (i) an issuance in August 2015 of $600.0 million in aggregate principal amount of 4.875% senior notes due March 1, 2026; (ii) borrowings in September 2015 of $400.0 million in aggregate principal amount of tranche B-1 and tranche B-2 term loan facilities under our amended and restated credit agreement dated January 9, 2015 (2015 Credit Agreement); (iii) borrowings under the revolving credit facility under the 2015 Credit Agreement; and (iv) cash on hand.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S6	See Note 11 for more information on the abovementioned debt instruments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P99_S7	The accompanying consolidated statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2015 included revenue, operating income and net income of $982.0 million, $27.7 million and $18.8 million, respectively, attributable to the GWS Acquisition.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P100_S0	and amortization expense related to intangible assets acquired of $24.2 million, all of which were incurred during the year ended December 31, 2015 in connection with the GWS Acquisition.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P100_S1	Unaudited pro forma results, assuming the GWS Acquisition had occurred as of January 1, 2015 for purposes of the 2015 pro forma disclosures, are presented below.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P100_S2	They include certain adjustments for the year ended December 31, 2015, including $47.5 million of increased amortization expense as a result of intangible assets acquired in the GWS Acquisition, $23.9 million of additional interest expense as a result of debt incurred to finance the GWS Acquisition, the removal of $48.9 million of direct costs incurred by us related to the GWS Acquisition, and the tax impact for the year ended December 31, 2015 of these pro forma adjustments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P100_S3	These pro forma results have been prepared for comparative purposes only and do not purport to be indicative of what operating results would have been had the GWS Acquisition occurred on January 1, 2015 and may not be indicative of future operating results (dollars in thousands, except share data):

1138118_18_ITEM8_P106_S0	The Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures topic (Topic 820) of the FASB ASC defines fair value as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P106_S1	Topic 820 also establishes a three-level fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P106_S2	This hierarchy requires entities to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P106_S3	The three levels of inputs used to measure fair value are as follows:
1138118_18_ITEM8_P107_S0	Level 1 Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P108_S0	Level 2 Observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level 1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P109_S0	Level 3 Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P109_S1	This includes certain pricing models, discounted cash flow methodologies and similar techniques that use significant unobservable inputs.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P110_S0	There were no significant transfers in or out of Level 1 and Level 2 during the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P111_S0	The following tables present the fair value of assets and liabilities measured at fair value on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 (dollars in thousands):
1138118_18_ITEM8_P112_S0	The fair values of the warehouse receivables are calculated based on already locked in security buy prices.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P112_S1	At December 31, 2017 and 2016, all of the warehouse receivables included in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets were either under commitment to be purchased by Freddie Mac or had confirmed forward trade commitments for the issuance and purchase of Fannie Mae or Ginnie Mae mortgage backed securities that will be secured by the underlying loans (See Notes 2 and 4).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P113_S0	These assets are classified as Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy as all inputs are readily observable.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P114_S0	The valuation of interest rate swaps and foreign currency exchange forward contracts is determined using widely accepted valuation techniques including discounted cash flow analysis on the expected cash flows of each derivative.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P114_S1	This analysis reflects the contractual terms of the derivatives, including the period to maturity, and uses observable market-based inputs, including interest rate and foreign currency exchange forward curves.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P115_S0	The fair values of interest rate swaps and foreign currency exchange forward contracts are determined using the market standard methodology of netting the discounted future estimated cash payments/receipts.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P115_S1	The estimated cash flows are based on an expectation of future interest rates or foreign currency exchange rates using forward curves derived from observable market interest rate and foreign currency exchange forward curves.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P115_S2	Fair value measurements for our available for sale securities are obtained from independent pricing services which utilize observable market data that may include quoted market prices, dealer quotes, market spreads, cash flows, the U.S. treasury yield curve, trading levels, market consensus prepayment speeds, credit information and the instrument's terms and conditions.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P116_S0	The trading securities and securities sold, not yet purchased are primarily in the U.S. and are generally valued at the last reported sales price on the day of valuation or, if no sales occurred on the valuation date, at the mean of the bid and asked prices on such date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P116_S1	There were no significant non-recurring fair value measurements recorded during the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P117_S0	FASB ASC Topic 825, Financial Instruments requires disclosure of fair value information about financial instruments, whether or not recognized in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P117_S1	Our financial instruments are as follows:
1138118_18_ITEM8_P118_S0	These balances include cash and cash equivalents as well as restricted cash with maturities of less than three months.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P118_S1	The carrying amount approximates fair value due to the short-term maturities of these instruments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P119_S0	Receivables, less Allowance for Doubtful Accounts Due to their short-term nature, fair value approximates carrying value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P120_S0	These balances are carried at fair value based on market prices at the balance sheet date.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P121_S0	Trading and Available for Sale Securities These investments are carried at their fair value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P122_S0	Foreign Currency Exchange Forward Contracts These assets and liabilities are carried at their fair value as calculated by using widely accepted valuation techniques including discounted cash flow analysis on the expected cash flows of each derivative.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P123_S0	Securities Sold, not yet Purchased These liabilities are carried at their fair value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P124_S0	The majority of this balance represents outstanding amounts under our warehouse lines of credit of our wholly-owned subsidiary, CBRE Capital Markets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P124_S1	Due to the short-term nature and variable interest rates of these instruments, fair value approximates carrying value (see Notes 4 and 11).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P125_S0	Interest Rate Swaps These liabilities are carried at their fair value as calculated by using widely-accepted valuation techniques including discounted cash flow analysis on the expected cash flows of each derivative (see Note 7).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P126_S0	Notes Payable on Real Estate: As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, the carrying value of our notes payable on real estate, net of unamortized debt issuance costs, was $17.9 million and $26.0 million, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P126_S1	These notes payable were not recourse to CBRE Group, Inc., except for being recourse to the single-purpose entities that held the real estate assets and were the primary obligors on the notes payable.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P127_S0	These borrowings have either fixed interest rates or floating interest rates at spreads added to a market index.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P128_S0	Although it is possible that certain portions of our notes payable on real estate may have fair values that differ from their carrying values, based on the terms of such loans as compared to current market conditions, or other factors specific to the borrower entity, we do not believe that the fair value of our notes payable is significantly different than their carrying value.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P129_S0	We are exposed to certain risks arising from both our business operations and economic conditions.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P129_S1	We manage economic risks, including interest rate, liquidity and credit risk primarily by managing the amount, sources and duration of our debt funding and by using derivative financial instruments.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P129_S2	Specifically, we enter into derivative financial instruments to manage exposures that arise from business activities that result in the payment of future known but uncertain cash amounts, the value of which are determined by interest rates.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P129_S3	Our derivative financial instruments are used to manage differences in the amount, timing and duration of our known or expected cash payments principally related to our borrowings.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S0	We do not net derivatives on our balance sheet.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S1	Our objectives in using interest rate derivatives are to add stability to interest expense and to manage our exposure to interest rate movements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S2	To accomplish this objective, we primarily use interest rate swaps as part of our interest rate risk management strategy.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S3	In July 2015, we entered into three interest rate swap agreements with an aggregate notional amount of $300.0 million, all with effective dates in August 2015, and designated them as cash flow hedges in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 815, Derivatives and Hedging .
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S4	We structured these swap agreements to attempt to hedge the variability of future interest payments due to changes in interest rates prior to us issuing the 4.875% senior notes (see Note 11).
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S5	In August 2015, we elected to terminate these agreements and paid a $6.2 million cash settlement, which was recorded to accumulated other comprehensive loss in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and is being amortized to interest expense throughout the remaining term of the terminated hedge transaction until August 2025.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S6	There was no hedge ineffectiveness for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S7	We reclassified $0.6 million in each of the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 from accumulated other comprehensive loss to interest expense.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P130_S8	During the next twelve months, we estimate that $0.6 million will be reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive loss to interest expense.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P131_S0	In March 2011, we entered into five interest rate swap agreements, all with effective dates in October 2011, and immediately designated them as cash flow hedges in accordance with FASB ASC Topic 815.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P131_S1	The purpose of these interest rate swap agreements is to attempt to hedge potential changes to our cash flows due to the variable interest nature of our senior term loan facilities.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P131_S2	The total notional amount of these interest rate swap agreements is $400.0 million, with $200.0 million having expired in October 2017 and $200.0 million expiring in September 2019.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P132_S0	The ineffective portion of the change in fair value of the derivatives is recognized directly in earnings.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P132_S1	There was no significant hedge ineffectiveness for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P133_S0	The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivatives designated and qualifying as cash flow hedges is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive loss on the balance sheet and is subsequently reclassified into earnings in the period that the hedged forecasted transaction affects earnings.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P133_S1	We reclassified $7.4 million, $10.7 million and $11.9 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016, and 2015, respectively, from accumulated other comprehensive loss to interest expense.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P133_S2	During the next twelve months, we estimate that $3.1 million will be reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive loss to interest expense.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P133_S3	In addition, we recorded a net gain of $0.9 million, and net losses of $2.4 million and $6.5 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively, to other comprehensive loss in relation to such interest rate swap agreements.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P133_S4	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, the fair values of such interest rate swap agreements were reflected as a $4.8 million liability and a $13.2 million liability, respectively, and were included in other liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S0	Additionally, our foreign operations expose us to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S1	These fluctuations may impact the value of our cash receipts and payments in terms of our functional (reporting) currency, which is U.S. dollars.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S2	We enter into derivative financial instruments to attempt to protect the value or fix the amount of certain obligations in terms of our reporting currency, the U.S. dollar.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S3	In March 2014, we began a foreign currency exchange forward hedging program by entering into foreign currency exchange forward contracts, including agreements to buy U.S. dollars and sell Australian dollars, British pound sterling, Canadian dollars, euros and Japanese yen.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S4	The purpose of these forward contracts was to attempt to mitigate the risk of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates that would adversely impact some of our foreign currency denominated EBITDA.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S5	Hedge accounting was not elected for any of these contracts.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P134_S6	As such, changes in the fair values of these contracts were recorded directly in earnings.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P135_S0	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016, we had no foreign currency exchange forward contracts outstanding as the program expired in December 2016.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P135_S1	Included in the consolidated statement of operations were net gains of $7.7 million and $24.2 million for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, resulting from net gains on foreign currency exchange forward contracts.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P135_S2	We also routinely monitor our exposure to currency exchange rate changes in connection with certain transactions and sometimes enter into foreign currency exchange option and forward contracts to limit our exposure to such transactions, as appropriate.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P135_S3	In the ordinary course of business, we also sometimes utilize derivative financial instruments in the form of foreign currency exchange contracts to attempt to mitigate foreign currency exchange exposure resulting from intercompany loans.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P135_S4	The net impact on our financial position and earnings resulting from these foreign currency exchange forward and options contracts has not been significant.

1138118_18_ITEM8_P139_S0	During 2017, we completed 11 in-fill acquisitions, including two leading Software as a Service (SaaS) platforms one that produces scalable interactive visualization technologies for commercial real estate and one that provides technology solutions for facilities management operations, a healthcare-focused project manager in Australia, a full-service brokerage and management boutique in South Florida, a technology-enabled national boutique commercial real estate finance and consulting firm in the United States, a retail consultancy in France, a majority interest in a Toronto-based investment management business specializing in private infrastructure and private equity investments, a San Francisco-based technology-focused boutique real estate brokerage firm, a project management and design engineering firm operating across the United States, a Washington, D.C.-based retail brokerage operation and a leading technical engineering services provider in Italy.

1138118_18_ITEM8_P140_S0	Our annual assessment of goodwill and other intangible assets deemed to have indefinite lives has historically been completed as of the beginning of the fourth quarter of each year.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P140_S1	We performed the 2017, 2016 and 2015 assessments as of October 1.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P140_S2	When we performed our required annual goodwill impairment review as of October 1, 2017, 2016 and 2015, we determined that no impairment existed as the estimated fair value of our reporting units was in excess of their carrying value.

1138118_18_ITEM8_P141_S0	Unamortizable intangible assets include management contracts identified as a result of the REIM Acquisitions relating to relationships with open-end funds, a trademark separately identified as a result of the 2001 Acquisition and a trade name separately identified in connection with the REIM Acquisitions, which represents the Clarion Partners trade name in the U.S. These intangible assets have indefinite useful lives and accordingly are not being amortized.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P142_S0	Customer relationships relate to existing relationships mainly in the brokerage, occupier outsourcing and property management lines of business that were primarily identified in the Trammell Crow Company Acquisition, the Norland Acquisition and the GWS Acquisition.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P142_S1	These intangible assets are being amortized over useful lives of up to 20 years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P143_S0	Mortgage servicing rights represent the carrying value of servicing assets in our mortgage brokerage line of business in the U.S.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P143_S1	The mortgage servicing rights are being amortized over the estimated period that net servicing income is expected to be received, which is typically up to ten years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P143_S2	In connection with the GWS Acquisition, trademarks of approximately $280 million were separately identified and are being amortized over 20 years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P144_S0	Management contracts consist primarily of asset management contracts relating to relationships with closed-end funds and separate accounts in the U.S., Europe and Asia that were separately identified as a result of the REIM Acquisitions.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P144_S1	These management contracts are being amortized over useful lives of up to 13 years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P145_S0	A covenant not to compete of approximately $74 million was separately identified in connection with the GWS Acquisition and is being amortized over three years.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P146_S0	Other amortizable intangible assets mainly represent transition costs, which get amortized as a reduction of revenue over the life of the associated contract.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P146_S1	Amortization expense related to intangible assets was $238.7 million, $211.7 million and $175.3 million for the years ended December 31, 2017, 2016 and 2015, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P146_S2	The estimated annual amortization expense for each of the years ending December 31, 2018 through December 31, 2022 approximates $216.2 million, $165.0 million, $138.2 million, $117.0 million and $107.1 million, respectively.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P147_S0	Investments in unconsolidated subsidiaries are accounted for under the equity method of accounting.
1138118_18_ITEM8_P147_S1	Our investment ownership percentages in equity method investments vary, generally ranging up to 5.0% in our Global Investment Management segment, up to 10.0% in our Development Services segment, and up to 50.0% in our other business segments.
